subject: RE: [junit] Tradeoff btw. right design and performance
msgSnippet: ...  ... Go not to the Elves for counsel, for they will answer both yes and no! (The same can be said for newsgroups and mailing lists! :-) That said,
messageBody:
>-----Original Message-----
>From: Rytrom [mailto:roman@...]
>Sent: Thursday, October 17, 2002 11:16 AM
>To: junit@yahoogroups.com
>Subject: [junit] Tradeoff btw. right design and performance

<snip>

>Why I'm asking this question in JUint group is 'cause I started
>practicing JUint recently and one of my badly-designed classes
>happened to be untestable (cause of such thought copling).
>As buffs of XP approach what do you preffer? Does it mean that every
>time a unit test can't be written for a function the function must be
>refactored?

"Go not to the Elves for counsel, for they will answer both yes and no!" (The same can be said for newsgroups and mailing lists! :-)

That said, the answer is yes and no. If you are able to take the time and have suitable resources available, then obviously you should refactor un-testable code until it is testable and provably correct. If the boss is leaning on you for a release and the wailing and gnashing of teeth is too much for you to bear, then don't test it. Just remember that there are very good reasons why XP adherents treat un-tested code like month old smelly socks!

Simon
